description: The first half of a two-semester intermediate sequence designed to help students attain a level of proficiency that should allow them to function comfortably in a French-speaking environment. Students are expected to have already learned the most basic grammatical structures in elementary French and will review these independently outside of class. This course will build on existing French skills and increase students' confidence and ability to read, write, speak and understand French. The course will additionally introduce students to more complex grammatical structures and more challenging cultural material. Out-of-class homework includes work with online, workbook and audio materials in addition to frequent writing practice.
name: INTERMEDIATE FRENCH I

values.comments:
French 130 is the first half of a two-semester intermediate sequence designed to help students attain a level of proficiency that should allow them to function comfortably in a French-speaking environment. Students are expected to have already learned the most basic grammatical structures in elementary French. This course seeks to build on students’ existing skills in French, increase their confidence and ability to read, write, speak, and understand French, and introduce them to more refined lexical items, more complex grammatical structures, and more challenging cultural material. Class is conducted entirely in French.

Students enrolled in the French 130 303 section had good things to say about both the course and Professor Ranalli. One stated that he/she “could not have asked for a better experience,” and another commented that this was the best French class he/she had taken. Class was considered “fun and interesting” and the experience taught students “useful expressions and information that would help [them] in real French settings.” Though one student felt that group work was sometimes cut off by the professor’s interjections, on the whole, and that the students themselves were sometimes unresponsive to questions, students had a sound experience in the course. 

Professor Ranalli was considered a “fantastic” and “masterful” French instructor. Students commended her for encouraging them to process information in French rather than fall into the habit of merely translating internally. They felt she was very willing to help students and encouraged them to participate through rewarding effort. As one put it, “she is an exceptional teacher and anyone is lucky to have her.” 

Class work included three chapter tests, weekly quizzes, and oral-based midterm and final exams. Additionally, students were expected to participate in class by means of frequent communicative activities such as role-plays, problem-solving tasks, discussions, and debates, often carried out in pairs or small groups.

This review is based on the 5 student comments that were submitted.

French 130 is the first half of a two-semester intermediate sequence designed to help students attain a level of proficiency that should allow them to function comfortably in a French-speaking environment. They are expected to have already learned the most basic grammatical structures in elementary French, and review these on their own in the course workbook. This course builds on existing skills in French, increase confidence and ability to read, write, speak, and understand French, and introduce students to more refined lexical items, more complex grammatical structures, and more challenging cultural material.   Students generally had positive things to say about this course. Many liked that they had the opportunity to practice their speaking skills throughout the semester.   Students only spoke positively of Professor Ciesco. Students attributed much of the success of the class to the way in which Professor Ciesco made them feel comfortable about speaking in front of the class. They also described Professor Ciesco’s attitude as enthusiastic and reported that she created a stimulating and enjoyable learning environment.   Students said that Professor Ciesco made herself very available to help. This review is based on the 5 student comments that were submitted.
